processed.result:
There are $n$ towns numbered from 1 to $n$.  Each town is connected to other towns by $n-1$ roads. The $i$-th road connects towns $u_i$ and $v_i$ and has a length of $l_i$.  

You need to close one road so that you can still travel between any two towns.  The "inconvenience" of the roads is the largest shortest distance between any two towns after you close one road.

Find the minimum possible inconvenience. 


Input:

* The first line contains the integer $n$ (3 ≤ $n$ ≤ 2⋅10⁵) — the number of towns and roads.
* The next $n$ lines contain the roads description. The $i$-th line contains three integers $u_i$, $v_i$, $l_i$ (1 ≤ $u_i$, $v_i$ ≤ $n$, 1 ≤ $l_i$ ≤ 10⁹) — the numbers of towns connected by the $i$-th road and the length of the $i$-th road.

Output:

* Print a single integer — the minimum possible inconvenience of the roads after closing one road.

You have a network of cities connected by roads. Each road has a length. You must close one road to minimize the longest shortest distance between any two cities.  What is the smallest possible longest shortest distance after closing one road?
